The morning sun filtered through the venetian blinds of Marcus Hartwell's cramped apartment kitchen, casting zebra-like shadows across the linoleum floor that had seen better days sometime around the Clinton administration. He stood at the counter, methodically spreading peanut butter on wheat bread while humming an off-key version of "My Way" – the same song he'd been rehearsing for months, the same song that had somehow, miraculously, gotten him to the finals of Britain's Got Talent.

Marcus paused mid-hum and shook his head, still unable to believe it. A thirty-eight-year-old high school English teacher from Johns Creek, Georgia, who'd never performed anywhere more prestigious than the faculty talent show, was now less than twelve hours away from stepping onto the most famous stage in British television. The sandwich-making resumed with renewed vigor as he contemplated the surreal turn his life had taken.

"Dad, you're doing that thing again," came a sleepy voice from behind him. Sophie, his fourteen-year-old daughter, shuffled into the kitchen wearing an oversized Atlanta Braves t-shirt and fuzzy slippers that had definitely seen better days. Her auburn hair, so much like her mother's had been, stuck up at impossible angles.

"What thing?" Marcus asked, though he already knew the answer. He'd been doing a lot of "things" lately – nervous habits that had multiplied exponentially since receiving the call from the BGT producers three weeks ago.

"The humming thing. And the foot tapping. And that weird finger drumming on every surface you touch." Sophie opened the refrigerator and pulled out a carton of orange juice, examining the expiration date with the skepticism of someone who'd learned not to trust her father's grocery management skills. "You're more nervous than when you had to give that speech at Mom's memorial service."

The mention of Sarah brought the familiar pang to Marcus's chest, but it was gentler now, more like the ache of an old injury before rain rather than the sharp stab it had been two years ago. "I suppose I am nervous," he admitted, handing Sophie her sandwich. "It's just... this whole thing still feels like some elaborate dream."

Sophie took a bite and studied her father with the unnervingly perceptive gaze that teenagers seemed to develop overnight. "You know you don't have to win, right? I mean, it's already pretty cool that you made it this far."

Marcus smiled at his daughter's attempt to manage his expectations, though part of him wondered if she was trying to protect herself from disappointment as much as him. The past two years had been a series of adjustments and adaptations, learning to navigate single parenthood while carrying the weight of his own grief and trying to shield Sophie from the worst of it.

"I know, sweetheart. But imagine if I did win. The prize money could pay for your college, maybe even graduate school. We could take that trip to Ireland you've been talking about." He leaned against the counter, his voice taking on the dreamy quality that had become familiar since this whole adventure began. "And maybe, just maybe, I could finally prove to myself that there's more to Marcus Hartwell than lesson plans and parent-teacher conferences."

Sophie rolled her eyes, but her expression was fond. "Dad, you teach kids about Shakespeare and Steinbeck. You help them discover stories and words and ideas that might change their lives. That's already pretty amazing."

Before Marcus could respond to his daughter's unexpected wisdom, his phone buzzed against the counter. The caller ID showed an international number he'd programmed weeks ago: BGT Production Office.

"Mr. Hartwell?" The voice on the other end was crisp, efficient, and distinctly British. "This is Jennifer Mills from the BGT production team. I'm calling to confirm your arrival time for tonight's dress rehearsal."

Marcus grabbed a pen and scribbled notes on the back of an electric bill. "Yes, I'll be there at four o'clock sharp. Is there anything specific I should bring or prepare?"

"Just yourself and your performance outfit. We'll handle everything else. I must say, Mr. Hartwell, everyone here is quite excited about your performance. It's refreshing to have someone with your... authenticity on the show."

After ending the call, Marcus found Sophie watching him with an expression that seemed far too mature for her fourteen years. "You're really going to do this, aren't you?"

"I am." The certainty in his voice surprised even him. "Sophie, I've spent the last two years just... existing. Getting up, teaching, coming home, helping with homework, making dinner, going to bed, and starting over. I love our life, I love being your dad, but when Sarah died, I think part of me died too. This competition, as crazy as it sounds, has made me feel alive again."

Sophie nodded slowly, then moved to give her father a hug that smelled like orange juice and teenager shampoo. "Then go show them what Marcus Hartwell can do."

The flight to London felt both endless and instantaneous. Marcus spent most of it alternating between nervous rehearsal – moving his lips soundlessly to avoid disturbing other passengers – and staring out the window at the Atlantic Ocean below. He'd flown internationally only once before, a honeymoon trip to Paris with Sarah that now felt like it had happened to someone else entirely.

The cab ride from Heathrow to his hotel provided his first real glimpse of London beyond airport terminals and tourism brochures. The city sprawled before him in a mixture of ancient and modern that his English teacher's heart found deeply satisfying. Gothic churches stood next to glass office buildings, black cabs navigated streets that had probably been cart paths when Shakespeare was writing his first plays.At the hotel, a modest but clean establishment in Bloomsbury that the production company had arranged, Marcus checked in with hands that trembled slightly as he signed the registration forms. The desk clerk, a young woman with a cheerful cockney accent, seemed to recognize something in his demeanor.

"First time in London, love?" she asked, handing him his room key with a sympathetic smile.

"Yes, and hopefully not the last," Marcus replied, attempting levity but hearing the nervous edge in his own voice. The clerk's expression shifted to one of curious recognition, and Marcus realized she might have seen his earlier performances on the show. The thought that strangers on the street might know who he was still felt surreal, like wearing clothes that didn't quite fit.

His room on the fourth floor was small but comfortable, with a view of a narrow street lined with Georgian townhouses that looked like they'd stepped out of a Dickens novel. Marcus set his single suitcase on the bed and immediately went to the window, pressing his palm against the cool glass as he watched London life unfold below. People hurried along the sidewalks with that particular urban purpose he recognized from his few visits to Atlanta, but everything here felt different – older, more layered with history and stories.

The rehearsal venue was a nondescript building in East London that gave no hint of the television magic created within its walls. Marcus arrived twenty minutes early, a habit ingrained by years of teaching that had served him well throughout the competition. Other contestants were already gathering in the lobby area, and he recognized several faces from previous rounds – the young dance troupe from Manchester, the opera singer from Wales, the comedian whose dry wit had made even the notoriously difficult Simon Cowell crack a smile.

What struck Marcus most was how different they all looked outside the bright lights and makeup of the actual show. The dancer who had seemed impossibly confident on stage was nervously adjusting her hair in a compact mirror, while the comedian sat quietly in a corner, running through what appeared to be last-minute material changes. It was oddly comforting to realize that his own anxiety was shared, that behind the polished performances they'd all delivered to get this far were regular people dealing with the same mixture of excitement and terror that currently churned in his stomach.

"Marcus Hartwell, right?" The voice belonged to a production assistant with a clipboard and the harried expression of someone managing too many moving pieces. "You're up third in the running order tonight. We'll need you in makeup at five-thirty, and remember – this is your only chance to rehearse with the full lighting and sound setup before tomorrow night's live show."

The reality of it hit him again like a physical force. Tomorrow night, millions of people would be watching. His students back in Johns Creek, his fellow teachers, Sarah's parents, neighbors he'd known for years – all of them would see him either triumph or fail on one of the world's biggest stages. The thought should have been paralyzing, but instead Marcus felt something unexpected: a calm settling over his shoulders like a familiar coat.

When his turn came to rehearse, walking out onto the stage felt like stepping into a cathedral. The auditorium stretched before him in shadowy vastness, the famous judges' table sitting empty but somehow still imposing. The lights were blindingly bright, and for a moment Marcus understood why some contestants seemed to freeze like deer caught in headlights. But then the opening notes of "My Way" filled the space, and something magical happened – the same transformation that had carried him through every round of the competition so far.

His voice, which had always been pleasant but unremarkable in the faculty lounge or shower at home, seemed to gain resonance and power in this space designed for dreams and disappointment. The song that Frank Sinatra had made famous decades before Marcus was born became something personal, something that spoke to every choice he'd made, every loss he'd endured, every moment of doubt he'd pushed through to stand on this stage.As the final notes faded into the vast empty space, Marcus stood in the silence for a moment, feeling the ghost of applause that would hopefully fill this theater tomorrow night. The production assistant gave him a thumbs up from the wings, and he could see the technical crew nodding approvingly as they adjusted lighting levels and sound equipment. Walking off the stage felt like leaving a church service – there was something sacred about the space that demanded reverence.

Back in the green room area, Marcus found himself gravitating toward the quiet corner where a cup of tea waited on a small table beside comfortable chairs that had probably witnessed countless pre-performance nerves over the years. The tea was stronger than he was used to, but the warmth was exactly what his hands needed as he processed what had just happened. The rehearsal had gone well, better than well actually, and for the first time since arriving in London, he allowed himself to believe that tomorrow night might actually be something special rather than simply something to survive.

"You've got a lovely voice," came a comment from nearby. Marcus looked up to see the Welsh opera singer settling into the adjacent chair with her own cup of tea. She was probably in her fifties, with silver hair pulled back elegantly and the kind of stage presence that suggested decades of performance experience. "Classical training?"

Marcus shook his head, suddenly feeling like an imposter among these clearly professional performers. "Just high school choir and church solos, nothing formal. I've always sung, but more for my own enjoyment than anything serious. Teaching has been my real career for the past fifteen years."

"Sometimes the best voices are the ones that haven't been overthought," she replied with a knowing smile. "There's something honest about your delivery that cuts right through all the technical perfection. The judges responded to that authenticity in your earlier performances, and I suspect tomorrow night will be no different."

Her words carried more weight than simple encouragement between competitors. There was a recognition in her tone that spoke to the deeper reasons people found themselves on stages like this one, reaching for something that regular life hadn't quite provided. Marcus suspected that beneath her polished exterior and obvious vocal training, she understood the same hunger for transformation that had brought him across an ocean to sing in front of millions of strangers.

The conversation drifted to more practical matters – the timing of tomorrow's show, the green room arrangements, the brief interviews each finalist would give to the backstage cameras. But underlying everything was the shared understanding that they were all standing at the edge of something that could change their lives forever. Some contestants seemed to carry the weight of lifelong dreams finally getting their moment, while others appeared to be grappling with unexpected opportunities that had found them rather than the other way around. Marcus definitely fell into the latter category, still somewhat amazed that a moment of wine-influenced boldness at his kitchen table had led to this surreal chapter of his life.

By the time he returned to his hotel that evening, London had transformed into the glittering nighttime version of itself that tourists photographed and guidebooks celebrated. Marcus walked the few blocks instead of taking a cab, needing the movement and fresh air to process the day's experiences. The streets were alive with people heading to theaters and restaurants, and he found himself imagining what it would be like to be a regular resident of this city rather than a visiting contestant whose entire future might pivot on the next twenty-four hours.

Back in his room, Marcus video-called Sophie, who answered from what appeared to be her homework-covered bedroom desk. The eight-hour time difference meant it was still afternoon in Georgia, and seeing her familiar face surrounded by the normal chaos of teenage life provided exactly the grounding he needed.

"How was the rehearsal, Dad? Did you forget the words? Trip over your own feet? Accidentally insult Simon Cowell?" Sophie's rapid-fire questions came with the kind of gentle teasing that had become their way of dealing with stressful situations since Sarah's death. Humor had been their lifeline during the worst months, when everything felt too heavy for normal conversation.

"No forgotten words, no physical disasters, and Simon wasn cowell wasn't even there for rehearsals," Marcus replied, settling back against the hotel room's headboard. "But Sophie, being on that stage... it's like nothing I've ever experienced. The lights, the space, the way your voice just fills every corner of the theater. I understand now why people spend their entire lives chasing this feeling."

Sophie nodded thoughtfully, and Marcus could see her processing this information with the careful consideration she'd developed for anything that might significantly impact their small family unit. "Are you nervous about tomorrow night? Like, really nervous, or just regular nervous?"

It was such a Sophie question – direct, practical, and focused on the emotional reality rather than the superficial excitement. Marcus considered his answer carefully, wanting to be honest without adding to whatever anxiety she might be feeling about having her father attempt something so public and potentially embarrassing.

"I'm nervous," he admitted, "but it's the good kind of nervous. Like the feeling you get before the first day of school or a big test that you've actually prepared for. There's excitement mixed in with the fear, and I think that's probably exactly how I should feel. If I wasn't nervous, it would mean this didn't matter to me, and it definitely matters."

They talked for another twenty minutes about school, her friends, the watch party that apparently half of Johns Creek was planning for tomorrow night's broadcast. Marcus learned that his fellow teachers had been following his journey with more enthusiasm than he'd realized, and that Sophie had been fielding questions and interview requests from local media with the poise of a seasoned publicist. The thought of his quiet, bookish daughter managing reporters while he sang his way through a British television competition struck him as beautifully absurd.

After ending the call, Marcus found himself standing at the window again, looking out at the London evening and thinking about the strange path that had led him here. Two years ago, he'd been a widowed father barely managing to keep his head above water, going through the motions of teaching and parenting while feeling like he was watching his own life from a distance. The decision to audition for Britain's Got Talent had been made in a moment of wine-influenced recklessness that he'd immediately regretted, then forgotten about entirely until the call came weeks later.

Now here he was, in a London hotel room, preparing to step onto one of the world's most famous stages and sing for a television audience that numbered in the tens of millions. The transformation felt so complete and sudden that he sometimes wondered if he was still the same person who had been making peanut butter sandwiches in his cramped Georgia kitchen just days ago.**Chapter 2**

The morning of the finals dawned gray and drizzle-soaked, the kind of London weather that Marcus had read about in countless novels but never experienced firsthand. He woke at five-thirty, his internal clock still stubbornly operating on Georgia time, and found himself staring at the ceiling of his hotel room while the city slowly came to life outside his window. The sounds were different here – the rumble of double-decker buses instead of pickup trucks, the clip-clop of heels on wet pavement instead of the suburban silence he was accustomed to back home.

His phone showed dozens of messages that had accumulated overnight, a mixture of good luck wishes from colleagues, excited texts from Sophie's friends, and even a formal note of support from his principal at Johns Creek High School. Reading through them while sipping the strong coffee he'd learned to appreciate during his London stay, Marcus felt the weight of everyone's expectations settling on his shoulders like a heavy coat. It wasn't an unpleasant feeling exactly, but it added a dimension to the evening ahead that he hadn't fully anticipated during his earlier rounds of the competition.

The production schedule for the day was meticulously planned, with each finalist's time blocked out in fifteen-minute increments that left little room for the kind of nervous wandering that Marcus might have preferred. A car would collect him at eleven for sound checks, followed by a media interview session, lunch with the other contestants, dress rehearsal, makeup, and finally the live show itself. The rigid structure was probably meant to prevent contestants from overthinking or psyching themselves out, but Marcus found himself craving just an hour or two of unscheduled time to walk through London and clear his head.

Instead, he spent the early morning hours in his hotel room, alternating between vocal warm-ups that probably annoyed the guests in neighboring rooms and anxious pacing that accomplished nothing beyond wearing a path in the carpet. The breakfast he'd ordered from room service sat largely untouched on the small table by the window, his appetite having apparently fled sometime during the night and showing no signs of returning. Even the full English breakfast that had seemed so appealingly foreign when he'd ordered it now looked like an insurmountable mountain of eggs and bacon and mysterious black pudding that his nervous stomach wanted no part of.

At precisely eleven o'clock, Marcus found himself in the back of a sleek black car that smelled of leather and expensive air freshener, being driven through London traffic by a cheerful driver who seemed to know every shortcut and back alley in the city. The conversation was light and distracting, exactly what Marcus needed as they navigated the maze of construction zones and pedestrian crossings that apparently defined London's relationship with vehicular movement. The driver, whose name was Colin and who had been transporting BGT contestants for three seasons, had an endless supply of encouraging stories about previous finalists who had gone on to successful careers regardless of whether they'd won their particular season.

"The thing about this show," Colin explained as they paused at yet another red light in an intersection that seemed designed by someone with a grudge against efficient traffic flow, "is that making it to the finals is already winning, isn't it? The exposure, the experience, the fact that you've proven you belong on that stage with the best acts in the country. Win or lose tonight, you're going home a different person than you were when you arrived."

His words carried the wisdom of someone who had witnessed this transformation repeatedly, who had driven nervous contestants to the theater and then driven them back to their hotels afterward, having seen their lives change in the span of a few hours. Marcus found himself wondering about all the people who had sat in this same seat, feeling the same mixture of excitement and terror that currently made his hands shake slightly every time he tried to check his phone for messages from Sophie.

The television studio in the bright light of day looked much less magical than it had during evening rehearsals, more like an industrial building than a palace of entertainment dreams. But once Marcus was inside, being guided through corridors lined with photographs of previous winners and memorable acts, the energy became palpable. Crew members moved with the focused efficiency of people preparing for a live broadcast that would reach millions of viewers, and everyone Marcus encountered seemed to radiate the particular brand of controlled excitement that came with working on something genuinely important.

The sound check process was more complex than he had anticipated, involving not just the obvious testing of microphones and audio levels, but also the coordination of lighting changes, camera angles, and the timing of his entrance and exit from the stage. Marcus found himself standing on pieces of tape that marked his optimal positions for different parts of the song, learning to hit his marks while still maintaining the emotional authenticity that had carried him through the earlier rounds. It was like learning choreography for a dance he had never performed, translating the intimate act of singing into something that would work for television cameras and a live audience simultaneously.

"Remember, Marcus," said the director, a intense woman named Patricia who spoke with the authority of someone who had been making television magic for longer than Marcus had been teaching, "the cameras will find you regardless of where you are on the stage, but we need you to trust the process and hit those marks. The lighting design is specifically calibrated for those positions, and that's what's going to make you look like the star you've become."

The casual reference to him as a star felt surreal, like she was talking about someone else entirely. Marcus Hartwell from Johns Creek, Georgia, had never been a star of anything more significant than the annual faculty talent show, and even that was stretching the definition considerably. But standing on this stage, with professional lighting designers adjusting spots and fills to make him look his best, with sound engineers fine-tuning equipment that cost more than his annual salary, he began to understand that he had indeed become something different from the man who had made that nervous audition tape in his living room months ago.

The media interviews that followed were a whirlwind of repeated questions and carefully considered answers, each conversation lasting just long enough for Marcus to find his rhythm before being whisked away to the next journalist or blogger or entertainment reporter. Everyone wanted to know about his journey, his background, his feelings about the competition, his plans for the future. The questions were predictable enough that he had developed a set of responses that felt authentic while still protecting the parts of his story that felt too private for public consumption.

What surprised him was how naturally the interview process had begun to feel after his initial awkwardness during the earlier rounds of the show. Teaching had apparently provided excellent training for thinking on his feet and communicating clearly under pressure, skills that translated well to explaining his unlikely path to this stage. When a reporter from a morning show asked him about performing in front of his largest audience yet, Marcus found himself giving an answer that surprised him with its confidence.

"The size of the audience doesn't really change the fundamentals of what I'm doing up there," he heard himself saying, wondering where this assurance was coming from. "Whether I'm singing to thirty kids in a classroom or thirty million people watching television, it's still about connecting with the song and letting it tell its story through me. The stage is bigger and the lights are brighter, but the essence of what makes music meaningful remains exactly the same."

Lunch was served in a private dining room that felt like a cross between a fancy restaurant and a school cafeteria, with round tables draped in white linens but filled with the nervous energy of students before a big exam. Marcus found himself seated with the dance troupe from Manchester, two of the comedians, and a magician whose close-up tricks during the soup course provided exactly the kind of distraction everyone needed. The conversation flowed easily between nervous jokes and genuine encouragement, creating a temporary bubble of camaraderie that made it easy to forget they were all competing against each other for the same prize.

"It's mental, isn't it?" observed one of the dancers, a girl who couldn't have been much older than Sophie but carried herself with the confidence of someone who had been performing her entire life. "Six months ago I was working at a coffee shop in Salford, and tonight I'll be dancing on the BGT stage in front of more people than live in my entire hometown. Sometimes I have to pinch myself to make sure I'm not dreaming the whole thing."

Her comment sparked a round of similar reflections from around the table, each finalist sharing the surreal aspects of their particular journey to this moment. The magician had been performing at children's birthday parties and retirement home events before his audition tape somehow found its way to the BGT producers. One of the comedians had never performed stand-up outside of open mic nights at a pub in Cardiff. They were all, Marcus realized, regular people who had been touched by some combination of talent, timing, and luck that had transformed their ordinary lives into something extraordinary.

The afternoon dress rehearsal felt different from the previous evening's practice session, charged with the energy of a full production crew preparing for a live broadcast. The theater was bustling with camera operators, sound technicians, lighting specialists, and dozens of other professionals whose coordinated efforts would transform individual performances into television magic. Marcus watched from the wings as the other contestants ran through their acts, noting how each performance seemed to gain an extra layer of polish and professionalism in this environment.

When his turn came, walking out onto the stage felt like stepping into a familiar room rather than the intimidating cathedral it had seemed just twenty-four hours earlier. The opening notes of "My Way" filled the space, and Marcus felt the same transformation that had carried him through every previous round of the competition. His voice seemed to find new resonances in the theater's acoustics, and he could sense the crew members pausing in their technical preparations to listen. There was something magical about the way a song could stop people in their tracks, demanding attention and emotional engagement even in the midst of the controlled chaos that surrounded a major television production.

As the final notes faded into the theater's vast spaces, Marcus stood for a moment in the silence, feeling the ghost of applause that would hopefully fill this room in just a few hours. Patricia, the director, gave him an enthusiastic thumbs up from her position behind the cameras, and he could see the lighting designer nodding approvingly as she made final adjustments to the spots that would illuminate his performance. Walking off the stage felt like leaving a sacred space, carrying with him the confidence that came from knowing he belonged in this rarefied atmosphere of professional entertainment.

The hours between dress rehearsal and the live show passed in a blur of final preparations, makeup sessions that transformed his everyday teacher appearance into something camera-ready, and the kind of nervous energy that seemed to infect everyone involved in the production. Marcus found himself in a dressing room that felt like a cross between a fancy hotel suite and a theater green room, complete with flowers from well-wishers, fruit baskets from the production company, and a mirror surrounded by light bulbs that made him feel like he was starring in his own backstage movie.The final hour before showtime brought a peculiar calm that Marcus hadn't expected. After months of building anticipation and days of intensive preparation, there was nothing left to do but wait and trust in the work he had already done. His dressing room, which had felt spacious and luxurious earlier in the day, now seemed to shrink around him as he sat in the makeup chair for final touch-ups. The makeup artist, a woman named Claire who had been working on television productions for over a decade, moved with the practiced efficiency of someone who understood that her job was about more than just making people look good on camera.

"You've got lovely bone structure," Claire commented as she applied a light dusting of powder that would prevent his face from looking shiny under the hot stage lights. "The cameras are going to love you. There's something very honest about your features that translates beautifully to television. Some people have to work quite hard to appear authentic on screen, but you've got that natural quality that can't be taught or faked."

Her professional assessment felt like a small gift of confidence at exactly the moment when Marcus needed it most. Teaching had never required him to think about how his face looked under bright lights or whether his expressions would read clearly to an audience of millions. The technical aspects of television performance had been an entirely new language to learn, adding layers of complexity to what had always been the simple act of opening his mouth and letting music emerge.

Through the thin walls of his dressing room, Marcus could hear the muffled sounds of the audience filing into the theater, their excited conversations creating a low hum of anticipation that seemed to vibrate through the building's structure. The knowledge that hundreds of people were taking their seats, checking their phones for final social media updates, and settling in for an evening of entertainment that would determine his immediate future, created a sensation in his stomach that wasn't quite nervousness but wasn't quite excitement either. It was something altogether more complex, a recognition that his life was balanced on the edge of a moment that would arrive whether he felt ready for it or not.

A gentle knock on his dressing room door interrupted his thoughts, followed by the appearance of Jennifer Mills, the production coordinator who had been his primary point of contact throughout the competition process. She carried the same clipboard and wore the same efficiently friendly expression that had become familiar over the weeks, but tonight there was an extra layer of energy in her demeanor that spoke to the significance of the evening ahead.

"Marcus, you're looking fantastic," she said, settling into the chair across from his makeup station with the practiced ease of someone who had delivered pre-show pep talks to countless nervous performers. "I wanted to check in with you one final time before we get into the thick of things. How are you feeling? Any last-minute concerns or questions that I can help address?"

The question was clearly part of her standard pre-show routine, but Marcus appreciated that she asked it with genuine interest rather than going through the motions. Over the course of his BGT journey, Jennifer had become something of a lifeline, the calm voice on the other end of the phone during moments when the whole experience had felt too surreal to process. She had guided him through contract negotiations, travel arrangements, media interviews, and the dozens of small logistical details that transformed a simple singing competition into a complex entertainment production.

"I think I'm as ready as I'm going to be," Marcus replied, studying his reflection in the brightly lit mirror and barely recognizing the polished version of himself that stared back. "It's strange how this whole thing has become simultaneously the most important thing I've ever done and somehow just another performance. Does that make sense? Like I'm carrying the weight of everything this could mean for Sophie and me, but when I think about actually getting up there and singing, it feels like the most natural thing in the world."

Jennifer nodded with the understanding of someone who had witnessed this particular psychological phenomenon many times before. "That's exactly how it should feel, actually. The contestants who struggle most are usually the ones who get so caught up in the stakes that they forget why they're here in the first place. You're here because you can sing, because you have something genuine to share with people, and because your voice has already moved audiences in ways that got you to this final. Trust in that foundation, and everything else will take care of itself."

Her words carried the authority of experience, and Marcus found himself storing them away as a mantra he could return to if his nerves threatened to overwhelm him during the long minutes between now and his performance. The BGT stage had seen countless dreams realized and shattered, careers launched and hopes dashed, and Jennifer had been witness to the full spectrum of human emotion that played out in these dressing rooms and backstage corridors. If she believed he was ready, if she had seen something in his journey that convinced her he belonged among the finalists, then perhaps he could trust in that assessment when his own confidence wavered.

The sounds from the theater were growing louder now, the excited chatter of the audience mixing with the technical announcements and sound checks that preceded any major live television production. Marcus could hear the distinctive voices of the warm-up comedians who entertained the crowd during commercial breaks, their practiced banter designed to keep energy levels high and create the kind of atmosphere that would translate into enthusiastic applause for the contestants. Somewhere beyond these walls, the judges were probably making their own final preparations, reviewing notes about each finalist and preparing for the live broadcast that would determine not just the winner of this season, but the trajectory of several lives hanging in the balance.

Claire finished her work with a final adjustment to his hair, stepping back to survey her efforts with the critical eye of an artist examining a completed canvas. "Perfect," she declared, beginning to pack away her arsenal of brushes, powders, and tools that had transformed his everyday appearance into something camera-ready. "Remember to blot your lips if they feel dry, but don't touch anything else. The lights will be hot, but the makeup is designed to handle that. You're going to look wonderful out there."

Alone in his dressing room for what might be the final time, Marcus took a moment to call Sophie. The time difference meant it was still afternoon in Georgia, and she would be getting ready for the watch party that had apparently grown from a small gathering of neighbors into a significant community event. The Johns Creek High School had opened its auditorium for anyone who wanted to watch the finals on the big screen, and according to Sophie's latest updates, the local newspaper was sending a photographer to document the hometown support for their unexpected international television star.

"Dad, you sound different," Sophie observed after they had exchanged the usual pre-performance pleasantries and mutual reassurances. "Not nervous different, but like... I don't know, more confident maybe? Like you've figured something out that you weren't sure about before."

Her perceptiveness continued to amaze him, this ability to read nuances in his voice across thousands of miles and through the slightly delayed connection of international phone service. Marcus considered her observation, trying to identify what might have shifted in his mindset between their conversation the previous evening and this moment of final preparation.

"I think I have figured something out," he replied slowly, working through the realization as he spoke. "For months, I've been thinking about this competition as something that was happening to me, like I was just along for the ride and hoping not to embarrass myself too badly. But sitting here now, getting ready to walk out onto that stage, I'm realizing that I actually belong here. Not because of luck or accident, but because I've earned it. Every performance, every round, every moment that got me to this point was me making choices and taking risks and proving that I could handle whatever came next."

Sophie was quiet for a moment, and Marcus could picture her processing this shift with the same thoughtful consideration she brought to everything that mattered to her. When she spoke again, her voice carried a note of pride that made his chest tight with emotion.

"I'm really proud of you, Dad. Not just for making it this far, but for becoming the person who could make it this far. Mom would be proud too. She always said you had more music in you than you let people see, and I think she would love knowing that the whole world gets to hear it tonight."

The mention of Sarah brought the familiar pang of loss, but tonight it was accompanied by something else – a sense that this entire journey had been, in some inexplicable way, connected to her memory and the life they had built together. Marcus had never been particularly mystical or given to believing in signs and cosmic interventions, but there was something about this competition that felt like a continuation of conversations he and Sarah had shared about dreams deferred and possibilities unexplored.

After ending the call with Sophie, Marcus spent his final minutes of preparation in quiet contemplation, sitting in the chair that Claire had vacated and studying his reflection in the theatrical mirror. The man looking back at him bore a resemblance to the English teacher who had made peanut butter sandwiches in a cramped Georgia kitchen, but there were differences that went beyond the professional makeup and carefully styled hair. The morning sun filtered through the venetian blinds of Marcus Hartwell's cramped apartment kitchen, casting zebra-like shadows across the linoleum floor that had seen better days sometime around the Clinton administration. He stood at the counter, methodically spreading peanut butter on wheat bread while humming an off-key version of "My Way" – the same song he'd been rehearsing for months, the same song that had somehow, miraculously, gotten him to the finals of Britain's Got Talent.

Marcus paused mid-hum and shook his head, still unable to believe it. A thirty-eight-year-old high school English teacher from Johns Creek, Georgia, who'd never performed anywhere more prestigious than the faculty talent show, was now less than twelve hours away from stepping onto the most famous stage in British television. The sandwich-making resumed with renewed vigor as he contemplated the surreal turn his life had taken.

"Dad, you're doing that thing again," came a sleepy voice from behind him. Sophie, his fourteen-year-old daughter, shuffled into the kitchen wearing an oversized Atlanta Braves t-shirt and fuzzy slippers that had definitely seen better days. Her auburn hair, so much like her mother's had been, stuck up at impossible angles.

"What thing?" Marcus asked, though he already knew the answer. He'd been doing a lot of "things" lately – nervous habits that had multiplied exponentially since receiving the call from the BGT producers three weeks ago.

"The humming thing. And the foot tapping. And that weird finger drumming on every surface you touch." Sophie opened the refrigerator and pulled out a carton of orange juice, examining the expiration date with the skepticism of someone who'd learned not to trust her father's grocery management skills. "You're more nervous than when you had to give that speech at Mom's memorial service."

The mention of Sarah brought the familiar pang to Marcus's chest, but it was gentler now, more like the ache of an old injury before rain rather than the sharp stab it had been two years ago. "I suppose I am nervous," he admitted, handing Sophie her sandwich. "It's just... this whole thing still feels like some elaborate dream."

Sophie took a bite and studied her father with the unnervingly perceptive gaze that teenagers seemed to develop overnight. "You know you don't have to win, right? I mean, it's already pretty cool that you made it this far."

Marcus smiled at his daughter's attempt to manage his expectations, though part of him wondered if she was trying to protect herself from disappointment as much as him. The past two years had been a series of adjustments and adaptations, learning to navigate single parenthood while carrying the weight of his own grief and trying to shield Sophie from the worst of it.

"I know, sweetheart. But imagine if I did win. The prize money could pay for your college, maybe even graduate school. We could take that trip to Ireland you've been talking about." He leaned against the counter, his voice taking on the dreamy quality that had become familiar since this whole adventure began. "And maybe, just maybe, I could finally prove to myself that there's more to Marcus Hartwell than lesson plans and parent-teacher conferences."

Sophie rolled her eyes, but her expression was fond. "Dad, you teach kids about Shakespeare and Steinbeck. You help them discover stories and words and ideas that might change their lives. That's already pretty amazing."

Before Marcus could respond to his daughter's unexpected wisdom, his phone buzzed against the counter. The caller ID showed an international number he'd programmed weeks ago: BGT Production Office.

"Mr. Hartwell?" The voice on the other end was crisp, efficient, and distinctly British. "This is Jennifer Mills from the BGT production team. I'm calling to confirm your arrival time for tonight's dress rehearsal."

Marcus grabbed a pen and scribbled notes on the back of an electric bill. "Yes, I'll be there at four o'clock sharp. Is there anything specific I should bring or prepare?"

"Just yourself and your performance outfit. We'll handle everything else. I must say, Mr. Hartwell, everyone here is quite excited about your performance. It's refreshing to have someone with your... authenticity on the show."

After ending the call, Marcus found Sophie watching him with an expression that seemed far too mature for her fourteen years. "You're really going to do this, aren't you?"

"I am." The certainty in his voice surprised even him. "Sophie, I've spent the last two years just... existing. Getting up, teaching, coming home, helping with homework, making dinner, going to bed, and starting over. I love our life, I love being your dad, but when Sarah died, I think part of me died too. This competition, as crazy as it sounds, has made me feel alive again."

Sophie nodded slowly, then moved to give her father a hug that smelled like orange juice and teenager shampoo. "Then go show them what Marcus Hartwell can do."

The flight to London felt both endless and instantaneous. Marcus spent most of it alternating between nervous rehearsal – moving his lips soundlessly to avoid disturbing other passengers – and staring out the window at the Atlantic Ocean below. He'd flown internationally only once before, a honeymoon trip to Paris with Sarah that now felt like it had happened to someone else entirely.

The cab ride from Heathrow to his hotel provided his first real glimpse of London beyond airport terminals and tourism brochures. The city sprawled before him in a mixture of ancient and modern that his English teacher's heart found deeply satisfying. Gothic churches stood next to glass office buildings, black cabs navigated streets that had probably been cart paths when Shakespeare was writing his first plays.

At the hotel, a modest but clean establishment in Bloomsbury that the production company had arranged, Marcus checked in with hands that trembled slightly as he signed the registration forms. The desk clerk, a young woman with a cheerful cockney accent, seemed to recognize something in his demeanor.

"First time in London, love?" she asked, handing him his room key with a sympathetic smile.

"Yes, and hopefully not the last," Marcus replied, attempting levity but hearing the nervous edge in his own voice. The clerk's expression shifted to one of curious recognition, and Marcus realized she might have seen his earlier performances on the show. The thought that strangers on the street might know who he was still felt surreal, like wearing clothes that didn't quite fit.

His room on the fourth floor was small but comfortable, with a view of a narrow street lined with Georgian townhouses that looked like they'd stepped out of a Dickens novel. Marcus set his single suitcase on the bed and immediately went to the window, pressing his palm against the cool glass as he watched London life unfold below. People hurried along the sidewalks with that particular urban purpose he recognized from his few visits to Atlanta, but everything here felt different – older, more layered with history and stories.

The rehearsal venue was a nondescript building in East London that gave no hint of the television magic created within its walls. Marcus arrived twenty minutes early, a habit ingrained by years of teaching that had served him well throughout the competition. Other contestants were already gathering in the lobby area, and he recognized several faces from previous rounds – the young dance troupe from Manchester, the opera singer from Wales, the comedian whose dry wit had made even the notoriously difficult Simon Cowell crack a smile.

What struck Marcus most was how different they all looked outside the bright lights and makeup of the actual show. The dancer who had seemed impossibly confident on stage was nervously adjusting her hair in a compact mirror, while the comedian sat quietly in a corner, running through what appeared to be last-minute material changes. It was oddly comforting to realize that his own anxiety was shared, that behind the polished performances they'd all delivered to get this far were regular people dealing with the same mixture of excitement and terror that currently churned in his stomach.

"Marcus Hartwell, right?" The voice belonged to a production assistant with a clipboard and the harried expression of someone managing too many moving pieces. "You're up third in the running order tonight. We'll need you in makeup at five-thirty, and remember – this is your only chance to rehearse with the full lighting and sound setup before tomorrow night's live show."

The reality of it hit him again like a physical force. Tomorrow night, millions of people would be watching. His students back in Johns Creek, his fellow teachers, Sarah's parents, neighbors he'd known for years – all of them would see him either triumph or fail on one of the world's biggest stages. The thought should have been paralyzing, but instead Marcus felt something unexpected: a calm settling over his shoulders like a familiar coat.

When his turn came to rehearse, walking out onto the stage felt like stepping into a cathedral. The auditorium stretched before him in shadowy vastness, the famous judges' table sitting empty but somehow still imposing. The lights were blindingly bright, and for a moment Marcus understood why some contestants seemed to freeze like deer caught in headlights. But then the opening notes of "My Way" filled the space, and something magical happened – the same transformation that had carried him through every round of the competition so far.

His voice, which had always been pleasant but unremarkable in the faculty lounge or shower at home, seemed to gain resonance and power in this space designed for dreams and disappointment. The song that Frank Sinatra had made famous decades before Marcus was born became something personal, something that spoke to every choice he'd made, every loss he'd endured, every moment of doubt he'd pushed through to stand on this stage.

As the final notes faded into the vast empty space, Marcus stood in the silence for a moment, feeling the ghost of applause that would hopefully fill this theater tomorrow night. The production assistant gave him a thumbs up from the wings, and he could see the technical crew nodding approvingly as they adjusted lighting levels and sound equipment. Walking off the stage felt like leaving a church service – there was something sacred about the space that demanded reverence.

Back in the green room area, Marcus found himself gravitating toward the quiet corner where a cup of tea waited on a small table beside comfortable chairs that had probably witnessed countless pre-performance nerves over the years. The tea was stronger than he was used to, but the warmth was exactly what his hands needed as he processed what had just happened. The rehearsal had gone well, better than well actually, and for the first time since arriving in London, he allowed himself to believe that tomorrow night might actually be something special rather than simply something to survive.

"You've got a lovely voice," came a comment from nearby. Marcus looked up to see the Welsh opera singer settling into the adjacent chair with her own cup of tea. She was probably in her fifties, with silver hair pulled back elegantly and the kind of stage presence that suggested decades of performance experience. "Classical training?"

Marcus shook his head, suddenly feeling like an imposter among these clearly professional performers. "Just high school choir and church solos, nothing formal. I've always sung, but more for my own enjoyment than anything serious. Teaching has been my real career for the past fifteen years."

"Sometimes the best voices are the ones that haven't been overthought," she replied with a knowing smile. "There's something honest about your delivery that cuts right through all the technical perfection. The judges responded to that authenticity in your earlier performances, and I suspect tomorrow night will be no different."

Her words carried more weight than simple encouragement between competitors. There was a recognition in her tone that spoke to the deeper reasons people found themselves on stages like this one, reaching for something that regular life hadn't quite provided. Marcus suspected that beneath her polished exterior and obvious vocal training, she understood the same hunger for transformation that had brought him across an ocean to sing in front of millions of strangers.

The conversation drifted to more practical matters – the timing of tomorrow's show, the green room arrangements, the brief interviews each finalist would give to the backstage cameras. But underlying everything was the shared understanding that they were all standing at the edge of something that could change their lives forever. Some contestants seemed to carry the weight of lifelong dreams finally getting their moment, while others appeared to be grappling with unexpected opportunities that had found them rather than the other way around. Marcus definitely fell into the latter category, still somewhat amazed that a moment of wine-influenced boldness at his kitchen table had led to this surreal chapter of his life.

By the time he returned to his hotel that evening, London had transformed into the glittering nighttime version of itself that tourists photographed and guidebooks celebrated. Marcus walked the few blocks instead of taking a cab, needing the movement and fresh air to process the day's experiences. The streets were alive with people heading to theaters and restaurants, and he found himself imagining what it would be like to be a regular resident of this city rather than a visiting contestant whose entire future might pivot on the next twenty-four hours.

Back in his room, Marcus video-called Sophie, who answered from what appeared to be her homework-covered bedroom desk. The eight-hour time difference meant it was still afternoon in Georgia, and seeing her familiar face surrounded by the normal chaos of teenage life provided exactly the grounding he needed.

"How was the rehearsal, Dad? Did you forget the words? Trip over your own feet? Accidentally insult Simon Cowell?" Sophie's rapid-fire questions came with the kind of gentle teasing that had become their way of dealing with stressful situations since Sarah's death. Humor had been their lifeline during the worst months, when everything felt too heavy for normal conversation.

"No forgotten words, no physical disasters, and Simon wasn cowell wasn't even there for rehearsals," Marcus replied, settling back against the hotel room's headboard. "But Sophie, being on that stage... it's like nothing I've ever experienced. The lights, the space, the way your voice just fills every corner of the theater. I understand now why people spend their entire lives chasing this feeling."

Sophie nodded thoughtfully, and Marcus could see her processing this information with the careful consideration she'd developed for anything that might significantly impact their small family unit. "Are you nervous about tomorrow night? Like, really nervous, or just regular nervous?"

It was such a Sophie question – direct, practical, and focused on the emotional reality rather than the superficial excitement. Marcus considered his answer carefully, wanting to be honest without adding to whatever anxiety she might be feeling about having her father attempt something so public and potentially embarrassing.

"I'm nervous," he admitted, "but it's the good kind of nervous. Like the feeling you get before the first day of school or a big test that you've actually prepared for. There's excitement mixed in with the fear, and I think that's probably exactly how I should feel. If I wasn't nervous, it would mean this didn't matter to me, and it definitely matters."

They talked for another twenty minutes about school, her friends, the watch party that apparently half of Johns Creek was planning for tomorrow night's broadcast. Marcus learned that his fellow teachers had been following his journey with more enthusiasm than he'd realized, and that Sophie had been fielding questions and interview requests from local media with the poise of a seasoned publicist. The thought of his quiet, bookish daughter managing reporters while he sang his way through a British television competition struck him as beautifully absurd.

After ending the call, Marcus found himself standing at the window again, looking out at the London evening and thinking about the strange path that had led him here. Two years ago, he'd been a widowed father barely managing to keep his head above water, going through the motions of teaching and parenting while feeling like he was watching his own life from a distance. The decision to audition for Britain's Got Talent had been made in a moment of wine-influenced recklessness that he'd immediately regretted, then forgotten about entirely until the call came weeks later.

Now here he was, in a London hotel room, preparing to step onto one of the world's most famous stages and sing for a television audience that numbered in the tens of millions. The transformation felt so complete and sudden that he sometimes wondered if he was still the same person who had been making peanut butter sandwiches in his cramped Georgia kitchen just days ago.

**Chapter 2**

The morning of the finals dawned gray and drizzle-soaked, the kind of London weather that Marcus had read about in countless novels but never experienced firsthand. He woke at five-thirty, his internal clock still stubbornly operating on Georgia time, and found himself staring at the ceiling of his hotel room while the city slowly came to life outside his window. The sounds were different here – the rumble of double-decker buses instead of pickup trucks, the clip-clop of heels on wet pavement instead of the suburban silence he was accustomed to back home.

His phone showed dozens of messages that had accumulated overnight, a mixture of good luck wishes from colleagues, excited texts from Sophie's friends, and even a formal note of support from his principal at Johns Creek High School.
